summary: A spontaneous encounter and conversation capturing Leland Sklar's personality and experiences.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a bald head and a beard, wearing a white t-shirt with the logo "ISHIBASHI MUSIC" and a lanyard around his neck, holding a microphone and speaking in front of a large poster at a trade show booth. The poster displays a black and white image of a man with long hair and a beard playing a bass guitar, with the text "Warwick Basses, Amps & Rock 'n' Roll" above the image. The man appears to be conducting an interview or providing commentary about the Warwick brand, which specializes in musical instruments. The setting is a bustling trade show environment with various booths and displays in the background, including a "FISHMAN" booth and a "SYSTEMS" booth. The atmosphere is lively, with other attendees and exhibitors visible in the background. The man in the white t-shirt is later joined by another man with long hair and a beard, who is wearing a dark t-shirt and has his arms crossed. The two men engage in conversation, with the man in the white t-shirt holding the microphone towards the other man, indicating an ongoing interview or discussion. The text at the bottom of the screen reads "Jason from ISHIBASHI MUSIC Shibuya, Tokyo Leland Sklar at the Warwick booth, NAMM 2015," providing context about the individuals and the event. The video captures the dynamic interaction between the two men against the backdrop of the trade show, highlighting the promotional activities of the Warwick brand.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker addressing bass players watching the video, hoping they know "who this gentleman right here is" and identifying him as "Lee Sklar", claiming he and Nathan East are two of the most "prolific recorded, live playing whatever base players in history." As the speaker's enthusiastic tone fades, another male speaker says "Memorex, I don't know" transitioning into a light-hearted conversation with the first speaker about who is real and losing his wristband for parking validation. The first speaker then says, "Well, ladies and gentlemen, this is the base player's base player, if there ever was one." The conversation ends with a casual greeting. Throughout the clip, background noise of traffic sounds hints at an urban setting.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures a lively scene at a music trade show, where two men are engaged in a conversation. The man on the left, wearing a white t-shirt with the text "ISHIBASHI MUSIC" and a lanyard with a badge, holds a microphone and appears to be interviewing the man on the right, who has a long white beard and is dressed in a dark t-shirt. The backdrop features a large poster of a man playing a bass guitar, with the text "Warwick Basses, Amps" visible, indicating the brand being showcased. The setting is bustling with activity, as other attendees and exhibitors can be seen in the background, contributing to the vibrant atmosphere of the event. The interaction between the two men is the focal point, with the interviewer gesturing and speaking into the microphone while the interviewee listens attentively, occasionally responding. The overall ambiance is one of professional engagement and enthusiasm for music-related products and discussions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with two male speakers recalling a meeting from the previous night. One speaker fondly remembers the event, while the other recounts being saved. They speak with friendly tones, with one remarking on how they enjoy the NAM show and that he normally spends all four days there. The speaker continues to describe his recent work in Florida and how he's using Sunday to catch up with everyone. He speaks enthusiastically, expressing his love for the show. The other speaker then mentions there may be a few people who don't know and prepares to introduce them. Throughout the audio clip, background music plays with a lighthearted and adventurous mood. The music includes piano and other instruments.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures an interview taking place at a bustling convention center, where a bald man wearing a white T-shirt with the "ISHIBASHI MUSIC" logo and a lanyard is holding a microphone and interviewing an older man with a long white beard and glasses. The older man, dressed in a dark gray T-shirt, stands with his arms crossed, listening attentively. Behind them, a large poster features an image of the older man playing a guitar, adding a personal touch to the setting. The background is filled with various booths and attendees, creating a lively atmosphere. As the interview progresses, text overlays appear on the screen, listing song titles and artists, such as "Rita Coolidge," "Lady's Not For Sale," "Fall Into Spring," and "It's Only Love," suggesting a discussion about music. The scene remains consistent, with the interviewee occasionally gesturing with his hands while speaking, and the interviewer maintaining a focused demeanor. The video effectively conveys the dynamic interaction between the interviewer and the interviewee, set against the vibrant backdrop of the convention.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about famous basslines. Another male speaker then responds in a conversational tone, listing songs he recorded bass lines for, such as "Your Smiling Face", "Doctor My Eyes", and "Stratus". He mentions having worked on around 2,500 albums. Throughout this dialogue, there is consistent, medium-volume ambient noise suggesting an outdoor environment with movement, possibly vehicles passing by.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures an interview taking place at a music convention, where a bald man wearing a white t-shirt with the "Ishibashi Music" logo is holding a microphone and interviewing an older man with a long white beard and glasses. The older man is dressed in a dark t-shirt and stands with his arms crossed, listening attentively to the interviewer. Behind them, a large poster displays an image of the same older man playing a guitar, adding a visual context to the interview. The background reveals a bustling convention hall with various booths and attendees, creating a lively atmosphere. The text "Ishibashi Music" is prominently displayed on the interviewer's shirt and in the top right corner of the screen, indicating the affiliation of the event. The video maintains a consistent setting throughout, with the interviewee and interviewer engaged in a conversation, while the convention environment remains active in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with two male speakers discussing recorded bass players, specifically Nathan East, and then Carol King. One voice expresses surprise at forgetting Carol King and acknowledges its profound influence. The speaker then transitions to expressing gratitude for still being a "working musician" and emphasizes that's all they care about. The background features an outdoor setting with ambient sounds.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an interview at a music convention, where a bald man wearing a white T-shirt with the "Ishibashi Music" logo and a lanyard is holding a microphone and interviewing an older man with a long white beard and glasses, who is dressed in a dark T-shirt. The background displays a large poster of the bearded man playing a bass guitar, and the convention hall is bustling with activity, including various booths and attendees. Throughout the interview, an inset video in the top left corner shows different live concert performances, including a man playing a guitar on stage, a band performing with vibrant lighting, and a man singing into a microphone. The inset video transitions between these performances, showcasing the energy and atmosphere of live music events. The Ishibashi Music logo and the number "4400" are visible in the top right corner of the screen, indicating the booth number at the convention. The interview continues with the interviewer and interviewee engaged in conversation, while the inset video provides a dynamic backdrop of live music performances.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing admiration for someone who took over a project with little notice, calling it "amazing." This speaker has an enthusiastic tone. The other male speaker then explains that they were in the middle of recording a solo album when someone became profoundly ill. He continues that they asked him to take over the project. To prepare, they sent him a copy of the show and he immersed himself in it for a week. He concludes that they did one rehearsal and then headed to Dubai to do the Jazz Festival. The tone of the second speaker is explanatory and informative. The audio clip also includes a jazzy musical element, which adds a cheerful and upbeat mood. There's a consistent background ambient noise, possibly related to outdoor activity.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an interview at a music convention, with a man wearing a white "Ishibashi Music" t-shirt holding a microphone and interviewing another man with a long white beard. The interviewer is wearing a lanyard with an ID badge, and the interviewee is dressed in a dark t-shirt. In the background, a large poster of a musician playing a bass guitar is visible. The setting is a bustling convention hall with various booths and attendees. Throughout the video, an inset screen in the top left corner displays different scenes from a live music performance, including a close-up of a musician singing into a microphone and a wider shot of the stage with multiple performers. The atmosphere is lively, with the interview taking place amidst the vibrant energy of the convention.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker stating, "I love working under pressure." He explains his preference for not using charts, stating he is "the kind of player..." The speaker's tone seems conversational. This is accompanied by background music that is difficult to clearly characterize, but appears to be fairly gentle.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an interview at a music convention, where a bald man wearing a white T-shirt with the "Ishibashi Music" logo and a lanyard is holding a microphone and interviewing an older man with a long white beard and glasses. The older man is dressed in a dark T-shirt and is gesturing with his hands while speaking. In the background, there is a large poster of the same older man playing a guitar, and the convention hall is bustling with activity, including other attendees and booths. The Ishibashi Music logo is visible in the top right corner of the screen. The interview takes place in a well-lit indoor setting, with the camera capturing the interaction between the interviewer and the interviewee.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with upbeat rock music playing, featuring instruments like guitar and drums. Over the music, a male speaker describes how he approaches learning music for tours. He says he has "charts in front of me," and he feels like he has to "look like I'm in the band," so he immerses himself, likening his practice to that of a "lab animal." Someone asks if he even sleeps. The speaker continues describing his dedication to learning the music, saying he listened to it constantly while driving around. He finds it a "hard thing to do" but mentions his previous experience learning 35 songs for a corporate event with Lyle Lovett in just a "couple of days." He then explains his preference for fan-fretted instruments due to their ability to reproduce low synth bass sounds. He also talks about meeting Sheldon Dingwall and the extended fan fretting with 37-inch B string. He notes that he's currently touring on the Warwick Starbass.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an interview at a music trade show, where a bald man wearing a white T-shirt with the "Ishibashi Music" logo and a lanyard is holding a microphone and interviewing a man with long white hair and a beard, who is wearing a dark T-shirt. They are standing in front of a large poster of the same man playing a bass guitar, with the text "Lee Sklar" and "The First Canadian Musical Company in the Music Industry" visible on the poster. The interviewee gestures towards the poster, pointing out details of the bass guitar, while the interviewer listens attentively. The background shows a busy exhibition hall with various booths and attendees walking around. The atmosphere is professional and focused on music-related discussions.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with speech from one male speaker, discussing "the bass I use on tour" and mentioning it "just got damaged by the airline." This is followed by another male speaker responding, recalling a conversation about it "yesterday" and noting it's "horrible." The first speaker continues, mentioning using tape to hold the base together, as "the body got damaged," explaining the electronics remained intact and he "gaffer taped" it. The second male speaker remarks "wow that's a long distance." The first speaker continues describing the damage, noting it's "all cracked." They conclude discussing repairs in Germany. Background music plays throughout, a jazzy style with a low-key, neutral tone, featuring instruments like an upright bass and guitar.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures an engaging interview at a music convention, featuring two individuals prominently. The interviewer, dressed in a white T-shirt with the "ISHIBASHI MUSIC" logo, holds a professional microphone, indicating a formal interview setup. The interviewee, distinguished by his long white beard and glasses, wears a dark T-shirt and appears to be a musician, as suggested by the large poster behind them depicting a similar figure playing a guitar. The backdrop includes the text "Rock 'n' Roll," reinforcing the musical theme of the event. The setting is bustling with other convention attendees and booths, creating a lively atmosphere. Throughout the video, the interviewee gestures expressively, indicating an animated conversation, while the interviewer maintains a focused demeanor, capturing the interview with the microphone. The interaction between the two is dynamic, with the interviewee's gestures and the interviewer's attentive stance contributing to the engaging nature of the scene.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing his affection for the instrument at hand, emphasizing its "off-the-shelf" nature and how he prefers not using custom-made equipment, for ease of replacement and repair. He mentions that the only modification made to the bass is the use of mandolin fret wire. Another male speaker responds with "That's great". The first speaker replies that he will play anything if it is not a horrible instrument. In the background, sounds of music playing imply the context may be a concert or performance setting.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, two men are engaged in a conversation at a music convention. The man on the left, wearing a white T-shirt with the "Ishibashi Music" logo and a lanyard around his neck, holds a microphone and appears to be interviewing the man on the right. The man on the right, with long white hair and a beard, is dressed in a dark T-shirt and listens attentively. Behind them, a large poster features a similar image of a man with a long beard holding a guitar, with the text "Rock 'n' Roll" visible. The setting is a bustling convention hall with various booths and attendees in the background, creating a lively atmosphere. The interaction between the two men is the focal point, with the interviewer gesturing and speaking while the interviewee responds, maintaining a professional and engaging demeanor throughout the conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing his love for playing basses he bought at flea markets for around $90. He contrasts this with a $10,000 bass he sold to John Entwistle. His tone is casual and anecdotal, followed by the sound of an interviewer interjecting in agreement and expressing interest. The first speaker responds to the interviewer, then the interviewer expresses amazement and assumes the speaker has a sizable collection. Ambient sounds are present throughout, with the consistent presence of music in an unknown style, accompanied by indistinguishable background noise that adds to a sense of environment.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a bald head and a beard, wearing a white t-shirt with the text "ISHIBASHI MUSIC" and a lanyard around his neck, is holding a microphone and interviewing another man with long white hair and a beard, who is wearing glasses and a dark-colored shirt. They are standing in front of a backdrop featuring a large image of a man with a long white beard playing a guitar, with the text "Rock 'n' Roll" visible. The setting appears to be a convention or trade show, as indicated by the booths and displays in the background. The interviewer is actively speaking and gesturing with his free hand, while the interviewee listens attentively and occasionally responds. The atmosphere is professional and focused on the conversation between the two men.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features an interview with a male speaker who describes himself as not a gearhead but owns about half a dozen basses. He expresses that his instruments are used in the studio and that he has sold and given away many items over the years. He mentions giving away instruments to friends' kids who want to study music, as long as they commit to it. He also shares that he gave a couple of amps to some friends who are good players but couldn't afford decent ones. The speaking tone throughout is conversational and friendly. Background music, categorized as either rock or metal, plays throughout the clip, adding a musical layer to the interview. The overall tone is positive and musical, with the interview providing context to the song.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a long white beard and glasses, wearing a dark gray t-shirt, standing in front of a backdrop with the text "Warwick Rock 'n' Roll" and an image of himself playing a guitar. He is being interviewed by another man wearing a white t-shirt with the "Ishibashi Music" logo, who holds a microphone and a recording device. The setting appears to be a music trade show, with various booths and displays visible in the background. The interviewer, identified as Jason from Ishibashi Music, is seen speaking to the bearded man, who listens attentively. Text overlays provide context, stating "Jason from Ishibashi Music Shibuya, Tokyo" and "Leland Sklar at the Warwick booth, NAMM 2015," along with the website "www.ishibashi.co.jp" and a Facebook link "www.facebook.com/IshibashiMusicJapan." The video concludes with a dynamic red graphic featuring the "Ishibashi Music" logo, emphasizing the brand's presence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker emphasizing the importance of staying humble at the top of one's game, as there are "a lot of branches to fall on your way back down." Another male speaker responds with agreement. The first speaker thanks the other for his time. The second male speaker replies, acknowledging it's a pleasure to see the first speaker after the first speaker "saved my ass last night". A third male speaker then confirms it was the right time and place. Following this conversation, electronic music plays.
